results.title: Inventing the future
results.creator_credit: Nancy Linde, WGBH Productions and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The dream machine”.
Looks at the development of commercial computer companies and the technologies and innovations that emerged in the 1950’s and 60’s. The designers and engineers Eckert and Mauchly set up the first computer company in 1946 but failed as businessmen. In England, the computer industry was co-operatively led by Cambridge University and Lyons (a company famous for tea and cakes). IBM entered the arena in 1951 when they recognised the need to compete with computers. FORTRAN and COBOL languages were developed to overcome the time-consuming problem of programming computers. Technological developments fuelled by the requirements of NASA’S space program and the Pentagon’s involvement in the Cold War witnessed the production of electronic components that were quicker, smaller, cheaper, more efficient and reliable.

results.title: Inventing reality
results.creator_credit: Richard Meech, Michael Grant and Biniman Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Millennium: tribal wisdom and the modern world”.
Have our needs for certainty and objectivity in our lives closed off the magical influence of the natural world? Is there a balance to strike? Follow narrator David Maybury-Lewis to the Huichol Indian villages of central Mexico to witness a Mexican doctor and a tribal shaman battling an epidemic of a rare strain of deadly measles. Then visit a cancer treatment centre in Toronto. Through these two examples understand how the certainties of science can combine with natural conceptions of physical disease. Then travel to the wilderness of Australia to ask the question: is reality something we shape as the Australian Aborigines believe, or vice-versa?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Meech, Michael Grant and Biniman Productions

results.title: Inventing number (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematics in the Infant/First School”.
Number is defined as a property of a set and the program shows how children are encouraged to ‘invent number’ by a skilful teacher. Also shows how each discovery is consolidated by playing games

results.title: Invasion of the virions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Investigates the different sorts of virions, where they come, and why they succeed in taking over so completely. Why they are so difficult to fight and how do the virions manage to hide away in the body only to re-emerge later.

results.title: Intrusive igneous rocks
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Unveils the rock-forming processing of magmas that do not reach earth’s surface but solidfy. Igneous rocks are classed as plutonic and volcanic; the differences are determined by the way the magma cools and hardens. Not all minerals are formed at the same time, and the crystalisation process results in different minerals being formed. Igneous activity is related also to Plate tectonics, while the moon is largely made up of igneous material rarely found on the surface of the earth.

results.title: Introduction to work sampling
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles and Oscar Patterson
results.brief_description: Points out that single or unsystematical observations may give quite erroneous ideas of how efficiently a worker is employed. Explains the “random” concept in statistics, using a bowl of 10,000 marbles of two colors. Applies the random sample method to a model of a machinist’s working day. Presents the claim that work sampling can provide many results of stop-watch time-and-motion study: standard hours of production work; average performance index; indication of idle time and delay causes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: University of California, Los Angeles and Oscar Patterson
results.description: Points out that single or unsystematical observations may give quite erroneous ideas of how efficiently a worker is employed. Explains the “random” concept in statistics, using a bowl of 10,000 marbles of two colors. Applies the random sample method to a model of a machinist’s working day. Presents the claim that work sampling can provide many results of stop-watch time-and-motion study: standard hours of production work; average performance index; indication of idle time and delay causes.

results.title: Introduction to video
results.creator_credit: John A. Givins, Lynn John and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Video tech”.
This introductory episode provides a basic outline of the various formats, how videotapes actually work, different sorts of video cameras - betacam, professional cams, consumer cams, the camcorder, and how to get good sound on the videotape.
